Class.name: DynamicQueryable
Class.Description: Provides a set of **static** methods for querying data structures that implement `IQueryable`. It allows dynamic string based querying. Very handy when, at compile time, you don't know the type of queries that will be generated, or when downstream components only return column names to sort and filter by.

Method.name: Where<TSource>
Method.Description: Filters a sequence of values based on a predicate.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable<TSource>` that contains elements from the input sequence that satisfy the condition specified by predicate.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IQueryable` to filter.

Argument.name: predicate
Argument.Description: An expression string to test each element for a condition.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a *basic value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
The following is an example of a *static argument value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
The following is an example of a *variable argument value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
Example.ExampleCode:
int someValue = 6;
IEnumerable<string> query = fruits.AsQueryable().Where("fruit.Length < @0", someValue);

Method.name: Where
Method.Description: Filters a sequence of values based on a predicate.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable` that contains elements from the input sequence that satisfy the condition specified by predicate.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IQueryable` to filter.

Argument.name: predicate
Argument.Description: An expression string to test each element for a condition.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a *basic value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
The following is an example of a *static argument value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
The following is an example of a *variable argument value* used in the `Where` string expression to filter a sequence.
Example.ExampleCode:
int someValue = 6;
IEnumerable<string> query = fruits.AsQueryable().Where("fruit.Length < @0", someValue);

Method.name: Select
Method.Description: Projects each element of a sequence into a new form.
Method.ReturnDescription: An `IQueryable` whose elements are the result of invoking a projection string on each element of *source*.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A sequence of values to project.

Argument.name: selector
Argument.Description: A projection string expression to apply to each element.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following code example demonstrates how to use `Select` to project over a sequence of values, using the `it` keyword.
The following code example demonstrates how to use `Select` to project a single field and a group of fields over a sequence of values.

Method.name: SelectMany
Method.Description: Projects each element of a sequence to an `IQueryable` and combines the resulting sequences into one sequence.
Method.ReturnDescription: An `IQueryable` whose elements are the result of invoking a one-to-many projection function on each element of the input sequence.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A sequence of values to project.

Argument.name: selector
Argument.Description: A projection string expression to apply to each element.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following code example demonstrates how to use `SelectMany` to perform a one-to-many projection over an array.

Method.name: OrderBy<TSource>
Method.Description: Sorts the elements of a sequence in ascending order according to a key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable<T>` whose elements are sorted according to the specified **ordering**.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A sequence of values to order.

Argument.name: ordering
Argument.Description: An expression string to indicate values to order by.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Method.name: OrderBy
Method.Description: Sorts the elements of a sequence in ascending order according to a key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable` whose elements are sorted according to the specified **ordering**.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A sequence of values to order.

Argument.name: ordering
Argument.Description: An expression string to indicate values to order by.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way `String.Format` formats strings.

Method.name: GroupBy
Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to a specified key string function and creates a result value from each group and its key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable` where each element represents a projection over a group and its key.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IQueryable` whose elements to group.

Argument.name: keySelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify the key for each element.

Argument.name: resultSelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify a result value from each group.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way String.Format formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a simple `GroupBy`.
The following is an example of a `GroupBy` using multiple key fields and multiple grouped fields.

Method.name: GroupBy
Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to a specified key string function and creates a result value from each group and its key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable` where each element represents a projection over a group and its key.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IQueryable` whose elements to group.

Argument.name: keySelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify the key for each element.

Argument.name: resultSelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify a result value from each group.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a simple `GroupBy`.
The following is an example of a `GroupBy` using multiple key fields and multiple grouped fields.

Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to a specified key string function and creates a result value from each group and its key.

Argument.name: source

Argument.name: keySelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify the key for each element.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicate as parameters. Similiar to the way String.Format formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a simple `GroupBy`.
The following is an example of a `GroupBy` using multiple key fields and multiple grouped fields.

Method.name: GroupBy
Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to a specified key string function and creates a result value from each group and its key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IQueryable` where each element represents a projection over a group and its key.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IQueryable` whose elements to group.

Argument.name: keySelector
Argument.Description: A string expression to specify the key for each element.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following is an example of a simple `GroupBy`.

Method.name: GroupByMany<TElement>
Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to multiple specified key string functions and creates a result value from each group (and subgroups) and its key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IEnumerable<GroupResult>` where each element represents a projection over a group, its key, and its subgroups.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IEnumerable<TElement>` whose elements to group.

Argument.name: keySelectors
Argument.Description: `string` expressions to specify the keys for each element.

Method.name: GroupByMany<TElement>
Method.Description: Groups the elements of a sequence according to multiple specified key string functions and creates a result value from each group (and subgroups) and its key.
Method.ReturnDescription: A `IEnumerable<GroupResult>` where each element represents a projection over a group, its key, and its subgroups.

Argument.name: source
Argument.Description: A `IEnumerable<TElement>` whose elements to group.

Argument.name: keySelectors
Argument.Description: Lambda expressions to specify the keys for each element.

Method.name: Join
Method.Description: Correlates the elements of two sequences based on matching keys. The default equality comparer is used to compare keys.
Method.ReturnDescription: An `IQueryable` obtained by performing an inner join on two sequences.

Argument.name: outer
Argument.Description: The first sequence to join.

Argument.name: inner
Argument.Description: The sequence to join to the first sequence.

Argument.name: outerKeySelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to extract the join key from each element of the first sequence.

Argument.name: innerKeySelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to extract the join key from each element of the second sequence.

Argument.name: resultSelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to create a result element from two matching elements.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicates as parameters. Similiar to the way String.Format formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following code example demonstrates how to use `Join` to perform an inner join of two sequences based on a common key using Dynamic LINQ.

Method.name: Join<TElement>
Method.Description: Correlates the elements of two sequences based on matching keys. The default equality comparer is used to compare keys.
Method.Remarks: This `Join` overload only works on elements where both sequences and the resulting element match.
Method.ReturnDescription: An `IQueryable<TElement>` obtained by performing an inner join on two sequences.

Argument.name: outer
Argument.Description: The first sequence to join.

Argument.name: inner
Argument.Description: The sequence to join to the first sequence.

Argument.name: outerKeySelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to extract the join key from each element of the first sequence.

Argument.name: innerKeySelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to extract the join key from each element of the second sequence.

Argument.name: resultSelector
Argument.Description: A dynamic function to create a result element from two matching elements.

Argument.name: args
Argument.Description: An object array that contains zero or more objects to insert into the predicates as parameters. Similiar to the way String.Format formats strings.

Example.HeaderRemarks: The following code example demonstrates how to use `Join` to perform an inner join of two sequences based on a common key using Dynamic LINQ.
